info.name: PAN-OS XML API
info.description:
This is a companion Postman collection for the official [PAN-OS XML API documentation](https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-panorama-api.html).

# Using this collection

To use the examples in this guide, you must define the following [variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/):

- **host**: IP address or hostname of the PAN-OS device you wish to interact with.
- **key**: A PAN-OS API key, which will be used in the `X-PAN-KEY` HTTP header.

# Request Structure

View the [official documentation](https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-panorama-api/about-the-pan-os-xml-api/structure-of-a-pan-os-xml-api-request.html).

A PAN-OS XML API request typically consists of the following parameters:

```
https://<firewall>/api/?type=<type>&action=<action>&xpath=<xpath>&key=<apikey>
```

- API key (`key=`): The API key allows you to authenticate yourself to the API when making requests.
- Request type (`type=`): The type of request you want.
- Action (`action=`): When the request type is `config` or `op`, you must also specify an associated action.
- XML and XPath elements (`xpath=` or `cmd=`): When using configuration or operation mode commands on the firewall, you include only the XML or the XPath that specifies the XML node.

Requests to the PAN-OS XML API can be performed using the `GET` and `POST` HTTP methods.


## GET Requests

Use a GET request when the query size is less than 2K and you want to pass strings in the request URL.  Append the query string to the request URL as a URL-encoded parameter string:

```
GET /api/?type=keygen&user=<username>&password=<password>
```


## POST Requests

Use a POST request when you are sending large amounts of form data (max request size of 5MB) or when you are passing non-ASCII characters.  Some API requests, such as importing files, require `POST`.  When using this method, pass the parameters in the request body, including the login credentials:

```
POST /api/ HTTP/1.1 
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded 
password=<password>&user=<username>&type=keygen
```

# Authentication

View the [official documentation](https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-panorama-api/about-the-pan-os-xml-api/structure-of-a-pan-os-xml-api-request/api-authentication-and-security.html).

To authenticate to the PAN-OS device, provide the API key along with your request in any of the following ways:

- The `X-PAN-KEY: <key>` HTTP header.
- The `key=` request URL parameter (must be URL-encoded).
- Use [Basic Authentication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_access_authentication#Client_side) to pass the admin credentials as `username:password` with Base64 encoding in an Authorization header field.

**Note:** You cannot use basic authentication with an API key.

See the [Generate API key](https://documenter.getpostman.com/view/2937330/7LgDQwG#5a6eec54-51a0-9716-fa38-5f894bf3c2ff) request for how to generate an API key.

# Error Codes

View the [official documentation](https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-panorama-api/get-started-with-the-pan-os-xml-api/pan-os-xml-api-error-codes.html).

The API response XML contains a status field and an error field.  These are the available API error codes and names:

## 400
- **Name:** Bad Request
- **Description:** A required parameter is missing, or an illegal parameter value was used.

## 403
- **Name:** Forbidden
- **Description:** Authentication or authorization errors, including invalid key or insufficient admin access rights.

## 1
- **Name:** Unknown Command
- **Description:** The specific config or operational command is not recognized.

## 2-5

- **Name**: Internal errors
- **Description**: Check with technical support.

## 6

- **Name**: Bad Xpath
- **Description**: The xpath specified in one or more attributes of the command is invalid.  Check the API browser for proper xpath values.

## 7

- **Name**: Object not present
- **Description**: Object specified by the xpath is not present.

## 8

- **Name**: Object not unique
- **Description**: For commands that operate on a single object, the specified object is not unique.

## 10

- **Name**: Reference count not zero
- **Description**: Object cannot be deleted as there are other objects that refer to it.

## 11

- **Name**: Internal error
- **Description**: Check with technical support.

## 12

- **Name**: Invalid object
- **Description**: Xpath or element values provided are not complete.

## 14

- **Name**: Operation not possible
- **Description**: Operation is allowed, but not possible in this case.  For example, moving a rule up one position when it is already at the top.

## 15

- **Name**: Operation denied
- **Description**: Operation is not allowed.  For example, admin not allowed to delete own account, or running a command that is not allowed on a passive device.

## 16

- **Name**: Unauthorized
- **Description**: The API role does not have access rights to run this query.

## 17

- **Name**: Invalid command
- **Description**: Invalid command or parameters.

## 18

- **Name**: Malformed command
- **Description**: The XML is malformed.

## 19-20

- **Name**: Success
- **Description**: Command completed successfully.

## 21

- **Name**: Internal error
- **Description**: Check with technical support.

## 22

- **Name**: Session timed out
- **Description**: The session for this query timed out.

query.description: Username used to generate API key.
Password used to generate API key.

request.description: Generates an API key for the given username and password.

query.description: Username used to generate API key.
Password sued to generate API key.

item.name: Get Running Configuration

request.description:
Gets the full running configuration.

Use `action=show` with no additional parameters to retrieve the entire active configuration.

response.name: Get Full Configuration

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success">
    <result>
        <config version="10.0.0" urldb="paloaltonetworks">
            ... example output truncated ...
        </config>
    </result>
</response>

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

request.description:
Gets a portion of the running config.

Use `action=show` along with the `xpath` parameter to target a specific portion of the configuration.

response.name: Get specific config portion

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success">
    <result>
        <security>
            <rules>
                <entry name="IT DNS Services" uuid="3e888b2c-7325-4778-ba20-4b0c90f92980">
                    <to>
                        <member>trust</member>
                    </to>
                    <from>
                        <member>untrust</member>
                    </from>
                    <source>
                        <member>any</member>
                    </source>
                    <destination>
                        <member>Data-Center</member>
                    </destination>
                    <source-user>
                        <member>any</member>
                    </source-user>
                    <category>
                        <member>any</member>
                    </category>
                    <application>
                        <member>dns</member>
                    </application>
                    <service>
                        <member>application-default</member>
                    </service>
                    <source-hip>
                        <member>any</member>
                    </source-hip>
                    <destination-hip>
                        <member>any</member>
                    </destination-hip>
                    <action>allow</action>
                    <log-setting>default</log-setting>
                    <profile-setting>
                        <group>
                            <member>Best-Practice</member>
                        </group>
                    </profile-setting>
                    <description>Inbound DNS requests to data center</description>
                </entry>
            </rules>
        </security>
    </result>
</response>

item.description:
The `show` action retrieves the running configuration.

The **running configuration** is the configuration currently active on the firewall.

item.name: Get Candidate Configuration

request.description: Gets the candidate configuration of the device.

response.name: Firewall candidate configuration

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success" code="19">
    <result total-count="1" count="1">
        <entry name="vsys1">
            ... example output truncated ...
        </entry>
    </result>
</response>

query.description: Serial number of the desired firewall

request.description: Fetch the candidate configuration of a managed firewall through Panorama, rather than by contacting the firewall directly.

response.name: Firewall candidate configuration through Panorama

query.description: Serial number of the desired firewall

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success" code="19">
    <result total-count="1" count="1">
        <entry name="vsys1">
            <application/>
            <application-group/>
            <zone>
                <entry name="untrust">
                    <network>
                        <layer3/>
                    </network>
                </entry>
                <entry name="trust">
                    <network>
                        <layer3/>
                    </network>
                </entry>
            </zone>
            <service/>
            <service-group/>
            <schedule/>
            <rulebase>
                <security>
                    <rules>
                        <entry name="IT DNS Services" uuid="3e08654f-472b-4a0e-aaac-9873ef45b51a">
                            <to>
                                <member>trust</member>
                            </to>
                            <from>
                                <member>untrust</member>
                            </from>
                            <source>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </source>
                            <destination>
                                <member>Data-Center</member>
                            </destination>
                            <source-user>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </source-user>
                            <category>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </category>
                            <application>
                                <member>dns</member>
                            </application>
                            <service>
                                <member>application-default</member>
                            </service>
                            <source-hip>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </source-hip>
                            <destination-hip>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </destination-hip>
                            <action>allow</action>
                            <log-setting>default</log-setting>
                        </entry>
                        <entry name="Outbound Access" uuid="c9c0bae4-ba99-4271-ab2b-2e87b0436240">
                            <to>
                                <member>untrust</member>
                            </to>
                            <from>
                                <member>trust</member>
                            </from>
                            <source>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </source>
                            <destination>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </destination>
                            <source-user>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </source-user>
                            <category>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </category>
                            <application>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </application>
                            <service>
                                <member>application-default</member>
                            </service>
                            <source-hip>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </source-hip>
                            <destination-hip>
                                <member>any</member>
                            </destination-hip>
                            <action>allow</action>
                            <log-setting>default</log-setting>
                        </entry>
                    </rules>
                </security>
                <default-security-rules>
                    <rules>
                        <entry name="interzone-default" uuid="3825e2ed-b9cc-4d92-abae-662faa0ea467">
                            <action>deny</action>
                            <log-start>no</log-start>
                            <log-end>yes</log-end>
                        </entry>
                    </rules>
                </default-security-rules>
                <nat>
                    <rules/>
                </nat>
            </rulebase>
            <import>
                <network>
                    <interface>
                        <member>ethernet1/1</member>
                        <member>ethernet1/2</member>
                    </interface>
                </network>
            </import>
            <address>
                <entry name="Data-Center-192.168.1.0-24">
                    <ip-netmask>192.168.1.0/24</ip-netmask>
                </entry>
                <entry name="Data-Center-192.168.2.0-24">
                    <ip-netmask>192.168.2.0/24</ip-netmask>
                </entry>
                <entry name="Old-Address">
                    <ip-netmask>1.1.1.1</ip-netmask>
                </entry>
                <entry name="New-Address">
                    <ip-netmask>1.1.1.1</ip-netmask>
                </entry>
            </address>
            <user-id-collector>
                <setting/>
            </user-id-collector>
            <log-settings>
                <profiles>
                    <entry name="default">
                        <match-list/>
                    </entry>
                </profiles>
            </log-settings>
            <profile-group>
                <entry name="Best-Practice">
                    <virus>
                        <member>default</member>
                    </virus>
                    <spyware>
                        <member>strict</member>
                    </spyware>
                    <vulnerability>
                        <member>strict</member>
                    </vulnerability>
                    <wildfire-analysis>
                        <member>default</member>
                    </wildfire-analysis>
                </entry>
            </profile-group>
            <address-group>
                <entry name="Data-Center">
                    <static>
                        <member>Data-Center-192.168.1.0-24</member>
                    </static>
                </entry>
            </address-group>
        </entry>
    </result>
</response>

item.name: Address objects in a virtual system

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

request.description:
Gets all the address objects in the candidate config for a specific virtual system.

Use `action=show` along with the `xpath` parameter to target a specific portion of the configuration.

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

request.description: Gets the full list of all applications defined on the firewall.

response.name: Full list of all applications

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success" code="19">
    <result total-count="1" count="1">
        <application>
            <entry id="120" name="100bao" ori_country="USA" ori_language="English">

                    </entry>
                </references>
                <default>

                        <member>tcp/3468,6346,11300</member>
                    </port>
                </default>
            </entry>
            <entry id="1797" minver="3.1.0" name="104apci-supervisory" ori_country="USA" ori_language="English">
                <category>business-systems</category>
                <subcategory>ics-protocols</subcategory>
                <technology>client-server</technology>
                <evasive-behavior>no</evasive-behavior>

                </default>

                </use-applications>

                <risk>2</risk>
                <application-container>iec-60870-5-104</application-container>
            </entry>
 
            ... example output truncated ...
        </application>
    </result>
</response>

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

request.description: Gets the details for a specific application in the firewall config.

response.name: Specific application details

query.description: XPath to desired portion of configuration

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success" code="19">
    <result total-count="1" count="1">
        <entry id="74" name="hotmail" ori_country="USA" ori_language="English">
            <category>collaboration</category>
            <subcategory>email</subcategory>
            <technology>browser-based</technology>
            <virus-ident>yes</virus-ident>
            <file-type-ident>yes</file-type-ident>
            <evasive-behavior>no</evasive-behavior>
            <consume-big-bandwidth>no</consume-big-bandwidth>
            <used-by-malware>yes</used-by-malware>
            <able-to-transfer-file>yes</able-to-transfer-file>
            <has-known-vulnerability>yes</has-known-vulnerability>
            <tunnel-other-application>no</tunnel-other-application>
            <prone-to-misuse>no</prone-to-misuse>
            <pervasive-use>yes</pervasive-use>
            <data-ident>yes</data-ident>
            <file-forward>yes</file-forward>
            <trusted-credential>yes</trusted-credential>
            <tag minver="9.1.0">
                <member>[Web App]</member>
            </tag>
            <references>
                <entry name="Wikipedia">
                    <link>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotmail</link>
                </entry>
            </references>
            <default>
                <port>
                    <member>tcp/443,995</member>
                    <member>tcp/80</member>
                </port>
            </default>
            <use-applications>
                <member minver="5.0.0">office365-consumer-access</member>
                <member>silverlight</member>
                <member>ssl</member>
                <member>web-browsing</member>
            </use-applications>
            <tunnel-applications minver="3.1.0">
                <member minver="3.1.0">sharepoint-online</member>
            </tunnel-applications>
            <risk>4</risk>
        </entry>
    </result>
</response>

item.description:
The `get` action retrieves the candidate configuration.

The **candidate configuration** consists of proposed changes to the configuration currently running on the firewall.  The `commit` action makes the changes in the candidate configuration active by copying them to the running configuration.

Changes that have not been committed will contain extra attributes related to what has changed:

- **admin**: Admin account that made the change
- **time**: Time the change was made
- **oldname**: In the case of a renamed element, the name it was previously

item.name: Set Configuration

request.description: Creates a new security rule named `IT DNS Services`.

response.name: Create new rule in security policy

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.name: Add an additional member to an address group

request.description:
Adds a new address object, `Data-Center-192.168.2.0-24` to the address group `Data-Center`.

Include the node you wish to modify in the xpath, and reference the specific entry by name.  Then, include the new members in the element parameter.

response.name: Add an additional member to an address group or list

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.name: Create a new IP address on a specific interface

request.description: Adds the IP address `5.5.5.5/24` to the `ethernet1/1` interface.

response.name: Create a new IP address on a specific interface

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

request.description:
Disables the rule `IT DNS Services`.

Conversely, use `<disabled>no</disabled>` to enable a rule that has been disabled.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
Use `action=set` to add or create a new object at a specified location in the PAN-OS configuration.  

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object in the configuration.
Use the `element` parameter to specify a value for the object you are adding using XML.

item.name: Edit Configuration

request.description:
Replaces the applications in the `IT DNS Services` rule with `dns`.

A portion of an object can be replaced by specifying the object's name within the `xpath`.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.name: Replace address objects in address group

request.description:
Replaces the address objects in the `Data-Center` address group with `Data-Center-192.168.1.0-24` and `Data-Center-192.168.2.0-24`.

The entire contents of an object can be replaced as well, but the name must be specified in both the `xpath` and the `element`.

response.name: Replace address objects in address group

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
Use `action=edit` to replace an existing object hierarchy at a specified location in the configuration with a new value.

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object, including the node to be replaced.  Use the `element` parameter to specify a new value for the object using its XML object hierarchy.

These requests are commonly performed after retrieving the existing object using `action=show`.

item.name: Delete Configuration

request.description: Deletes the security rule `IT DNS Services`.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.name: Delete a member from an address group

request.description:
Deletes the `Data-Center-192.168.2.0-24` object from the `Data-Center` address group.

To delete a single member object in a group, use a text match for the object's name in the `member` entries like this: `member[text()='Object-To-Delete']`.

item.description:
Use `action=delete` to delete an object at a specified location in the configuration.

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object to be deleted.

item.name: Rename Configuration

request.description: Renames the address object `Old-Address` to `New-Address`.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
Use `action=rename` to rename an object at a specified location in the configuration.

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object to be renamed.
Use the `newname` parameter to provide a new name for the object.

item.name: Clone Configuration

request.description: Clones the address object `Old-Address` to `New-Address`.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
Use `action=clone` to clone an existing configuration object.

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object to be cloned.
Use the `from` parameter to specify the source object.
Use the `newname` parameter to provide a name for the cloned object.

item.name: Move Configuration

request.description: Moves the rule `Outbound Access` after the rule `IT DNS Services`.

item.description:
Use `action=move` to move the location of an existing configuration object.

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object to be moved.
Use the `where` parameter to specify the type of move (can be *before*, *after*, *top*, or *bottom*).
Use the `dst` parameter to specify an object when `where` is *before* or *after*.

item.name: Override Configuration

url.raw: https://{{host}}/api/?type=config&action=override&xpath=/config/shared/log-settings/snmptrap&element=<entry name="snmp" src="tpl"><version src="tpl"><v2c src="tpl"><server src="tpl"><entry name="test" src="tpl"><manager src="tpl">2.2.2.2</manager><community src="tpl">test</community></entry></server></v2c></version></entry>

query.value: <entry name="snmp" src="tpl"><version src="tpl"><v2c src="tpl"><server src="tpl"><entry name="test" src="tpl"><manager src="tpl">2.2.2.2</manager><community src="tpl">test</community></entry></server></v2c></version></entry>

request.description: Overrides the SNMP trap profile configuration that was pushed to the firewall using a template.

url.raw: https://{{host}}/api/?type=config&action=override&xpath=/config/shared/log-settings/snmptrap&element=<entry name="snmp" src="tpl"><version src="tpl"><v2c src="tpl"><server src="tpl"><entry name="test" src="tpl"><manager src="tpl">2.2.2.2</manager><community src="tpl">test</community></entry></server></v2c></version></entry>

query.value: <entry name="snmp" src="tpl"><version src="tpl"><v2c src="tpl"><server src="tpl"><entry name="test" src="tpl"><manager src="tpl">2.2.2.2</manager><community src="tpl">test</community></entry></server></v2c></version></entry>

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
Use `action=override` to override a setting that was pushed to a firewall from a template.

Use the `xpath` parameter to specify the location of the object to override.

item.name: Multi-Move or Multi-Clone Configuration

request.description: Move the address objects `addr1` and `addr2` from the `socal` device group to the `norcal` device group.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

request.description: Clone the address objects `addr1` and `addr2` from the `socal` device group to the `norcal` device group.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description: Use the `action=multi-move` and `action=multi-clone` actions to move and clone addresses across device groups and virtual systems.  Templates do not support the multi-move and multi-clone capability.

item.name: View Configuration Node Values for XPath

request.description: Get all the possible values for `vsys` at this XPath.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description: Use `action=complete` along with an XPath to see possible values that are available with the XPath node.

item.name: Commit Configuration

request.description: Commit candidate changes to the firewall.

response.name: Commit

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success" code="19">
    <result>
        <msg>
            <line>Commit job enqueued with jobid 4</line>
        </msg>
        <job>4</job>
    </result>
</response>

request.description: Commit candidate changes to the firewall (force).

response.name: Force commit

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success" code="19">
    <result>
        <msg>

request.description: Commit shared policy to a specific virtual system.

item.description:
To centrally manage firewalls from Panorama, use the `commit-all` API request type to:

- Validate and push shared policy to firewalls using device groups.
- Validate and push configuration to firewalls and log collectors using templates and template stacks.

request.description: Retrieves the output of job id `6`, which was a commit job.

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
You can use the `commit` API request to commit a candidate configuration to a firewall.

Validating and reverting configurations are documented in the operational commands section.

request.description: Get details for threat signature '30003'.

response.name: Threat details

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

response.body:
<response status="success">
    <result>
        <entry name="30003" p="yes">
            <threatname>Microsoft Windows DCOM RPC Interface Buffer Overrun Vulnerability</threatname>
            <cve xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
                <member>CVE-2003-0352</member>
            </cve>
            <vendor xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
                <member>MS03-026</member>
            </vendor>
            <category>code-execution</category>
            <severity>critical</severity>
            <engine-version min="1.0"/>
            <affected-host>
                <server>yes</server>
            </affected-host>
            <default-action>reset-server</default-action>
        </entry>
    </result>
</response>

item.description:
Use any of the operational mode commands available on the command line with the `type=op` command.

Some operational commands, including download, upgrade, and installation requests, are asynchronous, meaning they require more than one request to get final results.

item.name: Get Reports
Dynamic Reports
item.description:
The following dynamic reports can be retrieved via API (use for the `reportname` parameter):

- `acc-summary`
- `custom-dynamic-report`
- `top-app-summary`
- `top-application-categories-summary`
- `top-application-risk-summary`
- `top-application-subcategories-summary`
- `top-application-tech-summary`
- `top-applications-summary`
- `top-applications-trsum`
- `top-attacker-countries-summary`
- `op-attackers-summary`
- `top-attacks-acc`
- `top-blocked-url-categories-summary`
- `top-blocked-url-summary`
- `top-blocked-url-user-behavior-summary`
- `top-data-dst-countries-summary`
- `top-data-dst-summary`
- `top-data-egress-zones-summary`
- `top-data-filename-summary`
- `top-data-filetype-summary`
- `top-data-ingress-zones-summary`
- `top-data-src-countries-summary`
- `top-data-src-summary`
- `top-data-type-summary`
- `top-dst-countries-summary`
- `top-dst-summary`
- `top-egress-zones-summary`
- `top-hip-objects-details`
- `top-hip-objects-summary`
- `top-hip-profiles-details`
- `top-hip-profiles-summary`
- `top-hip-report-links`
- `top-hr-applications-summary`
- `top-ingress-zones-summary`
- `top-rule-summary`
- `top-spyware-download-summary`
- `top-spyware-phonehome-summary`
- `top-spyware-threats-summary`
- `top-src-countries-summary`
- `top-src-summary`
- `top-threat-egress-zones-summary`
- `top-threat-ingress-zones-summary`
- `top-threats-type-summary`
- `top-url-categories-summary`
- `top-url-summary`
- `top-url-user-behavior-summary`
- `top-victim-countries-summary`
- `top-victims-summary`
- `top-viruses-summary`
- `top-vulnerabilities-summary`

For dynamic reports, provide either a specific period using the `period` parameter, or a time frame using the `starttime` and `endtime` parameters (use a `+` instead of a space between the date and timestamp).  Use the `topn` parameter to determine the number of rows.

query.description: Report ID to retrieve results for

item.description:
Results of any report defined in the system can be retrieved using the `type=report` parameter:

The three types of reports that can be retrieved are:

- Dynamic Reports (ACC reports) - `reporttype=dynamic`
- Predefined Reports - `reporttype=predefined`
- Custom Reports - `reporttype=custom`

To retrieve a specific report by name, use the `reportname` parameter.

When you request a report, the API responds asyncronously with a job ID, which you can use to retrieve the reports.  See the [Retrieve report results](https://documenter.getpostman.com/view/2937330/7LgDQwG#cb8a1f2f-df9c-4c9f-b6dc-f67650ddbeb2) API call for retrieving the results.

item.name: Get Version Info

header.value: GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS

item.description:
Use this request to show:

- PAN-OS version
- Serial number
- Model number
- Multi-vsys capability
